user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarGetInfo(osal_id_t var_id, OS_condvar_prop_t *condvar_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(condvar_prop);

    memset(condvar_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_condvar_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_condvar_table, token);

        strncpy(condvar_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(condvar_prop->name) - 1);
        condvar_prop->creator = record->creator;

        return_code = OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl(&token, condvar_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_condvar_prop_t *condvar_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
} OS_condvar_prop_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any code fragment that reassigns or otherwise modifies a function parameter itself (which would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8). Specific notes to justify not flagging other fragments:

- The pointer parameter condvar_prop is used with memset, strncpy and field assignments (memset(condvar_prop,...), strncpy(condvar_prop->name,...), condvar_prop->creator = ...). These modify the object pointed to, which is allowed by the rule; the pointer value itself is never reassigned.
- The scalar parameter var_id is not modified anywhere in the function.
- OS_CHECK_POINTER(condvar_prop) only performs a null-check via the BUGCHECK macro; it does not modify the pointer.
- The token variable is a local variable (OS_object_token_t token). Passing &token to macros and functions (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(..., token), OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl(&token,...), OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token)) operates on the local variable or the object it points to; it is not a reassignment of a function parameter.
- OS_CondVarGetInfo_Impl declares its first parameter as const OS_object_token_t *token, so that function cannot modify the token object via that parameter; the second parameter is a non-const pointer but again only the pointed-to object may be modified (allowed).
- Other related functions shown (OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdRelease) use pointer parameters to populate or operate on the pointed-to structure (e.g., token->obj_idx, token->obj_id), which is allowed under the rule.

Therefore there are no apparent violations of Rule 17.8 in the provided code fragments.
